questions.text: A boy presents with pallor and lymphadenopathy; the X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following drug is not used for the management of the suspected diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Vincristine

Explanation:

  • • Options A. Cyclophosphamide: Explanation
  • • Options B. Methotrexate: Explanation : Methotrexate is used to treat LCH by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.
  • • Options B. Methotrexate: Explanation
  • • Options C. Vinblastine: Explanation : Vinblastine is commonly used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children, by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells.
  • • Options C. Vinblastine: Explanation
  • • Options D. Vincristine: Explanation : Vincristine is not recommended for LCH. Other chemotherapy drugs like vinblastine are preferred for this condition.
  • • Options D. Vincristine: Explanation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH) is treated with various chemotherapy drugs, but vincristine is not typically used for this condition. Vinblastine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and other drugs are preferred for the management of LCH.

questions.text: The maximum dose of PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 mg

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Prostaglandin F2 alpha (PGF2α), also known as carboprost, is used for the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to uterine atony. The therapeutic regimen and maximum dosage are crucial for effective management and patient safety.
  • • Dose and Administration: The approved dose for treating uterine atony with PGF2α is 0.25 mg administered intramuscularly (IM). Maximum Dose: The maximum cumulative dose is 2 mg. This is achieved by administering a total of 8 doses of 0.25 mg each. Dosing Interval: These doses can be repeated at intervals of 15 to 90 minutes, depending on the clinical response and the patient's condition.
  • • Dose and Administration: The approved dose for treating uterine atony with PGF2α is 0.25 mg administered intramuscularly (IM).
  • • Dose and Administration:
  • • Maximum Dose: The maximum cumulative dose is 2 mg. This is achieved by administering a total of 8 doses of 0.25 mg each.
  • • Maximum Dose:
  • • Dosing Interval: These doses can be repeated at intervals of 15 to 90 minutes, depending on the clinical response and the patient's condition.
  • • Dosing Interval:
  • • Contraindications
  • • Contraindications
  • • Bronchial Asthma: PGF2α can cause bronchoconstriction, which makes it contraindicated in patients with bronchial asthma. Suspected Amniotic Fluid Embolism: Due to its potential to cause pulmonary airway and vascular constriction, it is also contraindicated in cases of suspected amniotic fluid embolism.
  • • Bronchial Asthma: PGF2α can cause bronchoconstriction, which makes it contraindicated in patients with bronchial asthma.
  • • Bronchial Asthma:
  • • Suspected Amniotic Fluid Embolism: Due to its potential to cause pulmonary airway and vascular constriction, it is also contraindicated in cases of suspected amniotic fluid embolism.
  • • Suspected Amniotic Fluid Embolism:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 0.25 mg : This is the single dose administered IM but not the cumulative maximum dose.
  • • Option A. 0.25 mg
  • • Option C. 20 mg : This dose is excessively high and not clinically recommended or safe.
  • • Option C. 20 mg
  • • Option D. 200 mg : This dose is not applicable for human use and is far beyond the safe and recommended limits.
  • • Option D. 200 mg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The maximum dose of prostaglandin F2 alpha in the management of postpartum hemorrhage is 2 mg, administered in 0.25 mg increments intramuscularly.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 480, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 480, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition

questions.text: A patient with 6 weeks amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test came with complaints of lower abdominal pain, moderate bleeding PV. She was hemodynamically stable. On ultrasound, there was no gestational sac in the uterus. Ovaries were normal and no free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Follow-up with beta-HCG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, a positive pregnancy test, and no gestational sac visible on ultrasound, the next step is to follow up with serial beta-HCG levels to differentiate between an early intrauterine pregnancy, an ectopic pregnancy, and a miscarriage.
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg 356
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg 356

questions.text: The most probable diagnosis for a young male presenting with Leucotrichia and lesions as depicted in the image is? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Segmental vitiligo

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Segmental vitiligo presents with one or more macules in a dermatomal or segmental pattern, often accompanied by Leucotrichia.
  • ➤ Segmental vitiligo
  • ➤ dermatomal or segmental
  • ➤ Leucotrichia.

  • ➤ Ref - Rooks Textbook of dermatology 9 th Edition page no 88.34

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child with a body weight of 15kg and height of 100cm is admitted with renal failure. His blood urea was 100 mg/dL and serum creatinine was 1 mg/dL. What is the closest calculated eGFR in the patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 40 ml/min/1.73 m2 BSA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) in pediatric patients can be calculated using the Schwartz formula, which is widely used in clinical practice. The formula takes into account the patient's height and serum creatinine levels, along with a constant value that is adjusted for age and sex.
  • ➤ The modified Schwartz formula is most commonly used for this purpose. It is given as:
  • ➤ For children aged 1 to 16 years, the constant k is typically 0.413
  • ➤ Given the child's height of 100 cm and serum creatinine of 1 mg/dL:
  • ➤ The closest value provided in the options is 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA, which is therefore the correct answer
  • ➤ Understand and apply the Schwartz formula for estimating eGFR in pediatric patients based on height and serum creatinine levels.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs cause visual problems as an adverse effect? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ethambutol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethambutol is the anti-tubercular drug known for its association with visual problems. It can cause optic neuritis and changes in color vision, which may be reversible upon discontinuation of the drug.

questions.text: Arrange lung hilar structures from anterior to posterior: 1. Primary bronchus 2. Bronchial artery 3. Pulmonary vein 4. Pulmonary artery
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Lung hilar structures are arranged from the anterior to posterior in the order:
  • • Pulmonary vein Pulmonary artery Primary bronchus Bronchial artery
  • • Pulmonary vein
  • • Pulmonary artery
  • • Primary bronchus
  • • Bronchial artery
  • • The superior vena cava and right atrium are seen in front of the right root and terminal part of the azygos vein superiorly. The hilar structures are arranged from the superior to inferior as:
  • • Superior lobar bronchus Pulmonary artery Principal bronchus Inferior pulmonary vein
  • • Superior lobar bronchus
  • • Pulmonary artery
  • • Principal bronchus
  • • Inferior pulmonary vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Anastrozole

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Methotrexate acts by inhibiting: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dihydrofolate reductase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient has just delivered a full-term baby and developed uterine inversion with the placenta still attached. What is the immediate next step? (INICET NOV 2023)

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Put uterus inside without removing the placenta

options.label: C
options.text: Shift to OT and insert the uterus back

questions.correct_answer: B. Put uterus inside without removing the placenta
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Put uterus inside without removing the placenta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the case of uterine inversion, the uterus should be repositioned with the placenta still attached to avoid significant bleeding, followed by medical management for uterine contraction.

questions.text: What is Edmond Locard known for? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Theory of exchange

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Edmond Locard is best known for Locard's Exchange Principle, which states that whenever two bodies come into contact, there is an exchange of materials, thereby linking criminals to crime scenes.

questions.text: Identify the condition that does not lead to bilateral hydronephrosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Retrocaval ureter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old female developed pruritic papules with excoriated plaques in the interdigital web spaces. Later the lesion spread to the groin and under-surface of the breasts. The lady gives a history of intense pruritus which is more severe at night. Given below is the organism responsible for this condition. Identify the wrong statement about the same? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: C
options.text: ﻿﻿﻿The entire life cycle takes about 15 days

questions.correct_answer: D. ﻿﻿﻿Male parasite burrows into the epidermis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The female Sarcoptes scabiei mite is responsible for burrowing into the skin and laying eggs, which leads to the intense itching and characteristic rash seen in scabies. Recognizing the specific behavior of the female mite in the transmission and lifecycle of scabies is crucial for effective diagnosis and management of the condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient visits his family practitioner for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg. His pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Arterial wall compliance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, resulting in higher systolic blood pressure and an increased pulse pressure, as observed in the patient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who had undergone an uneventful cataract surgery with intraocular lens implantation, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance in the operated eye, 36 hours post operatively. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Intravitreal antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intravitreal antibiotics are the primary treatment for endophthalmitis, a severe postoperative complication characterized by inflammation and hypopyon. Early and aggressive treatment is crucial to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: Calculate the median from the given set of observations: 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 4, 8. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which trisomy is suggested by karyotyping results showing chromosomal defects? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Edward syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Edward syndrome is caused by Trisomy 18, where the karyotype reveals an extra chromosome 18. This distinguishes it from other chromosomal disorders such as Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) and Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13)

questions.text: Image of a patient with large ulcerated breast cancer with liver metastasis. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Simple mastectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with stage IV breast cancer with distant metastasis, such as liver metastasis, the primary focus is on palliation. Simple mastectomy may be performed to manage symptoms from a large ulcerated tumor, but more extensive surgeries or curative approaches are not indicated.

questions.text: Ammonia is transported from the brain to the liver in the form of which of the following amino acids? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glutamine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Ammonia is transported from the brain to the liver primarily in the form of glutamine.
  • • This is because glutamine can safely carry ammonia through the bloodstream to the liver, where the urea cycle converts it into urea for excretion.
  • • The liver's urea cycle is the primary site for detoxifying ammonia, a neurotoxic byproduct of amino acid metabolism.
  • • Glutamine plays a crucial role in this process by acting as a carrier molecule that neutralizes ammonia, thus preventing its accumulation and potential toxicity in the brain.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Glutamate: While glutamate is involved in ammonia metabolism, it is not the primary transporter of ammonia from the brain to the liver. Instead, glutamate is often converted to glutamine for this purpose.
  • • Option A. Glutamate:
  • • Option B. Alanine: Alanine transports ammonia primarily from muscle tissues to the liver. It is part of the glucose-alanine cycle, which helps in the conversion of pyruvate to glucose in the liver.
  • • Option B. Alanine:
  • • muscle tissues
  • • Option C. Glycine: Glycine does not play a significant role in ammonia transport from the brain to the liver.
  • • Option C. Glycine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glutamine is the primary amino acid responsible for transporting ammonia from the brain to the liver.

questions.text: In a suspected case of cholangitis in a 47-year-old woman, what other component besides abdominal pain does not comprise Reynold's pentad? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hematemesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholangitis is an infection of the common bile duct caused by obstruction and increased pressure due to CBD stones. The classical triad of cholangitis (Charcot) is fever, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice. If left untreated, cholangitis can progress to Reynold's pentad with hypotension and altered mental status due to sepsis. Abdominal ultrasound is used to diagnose biliary stones and bile duct dilatations in cholangitis. Treatment for cholangitis includes broad-spectrum antibiotics, rehydration, and biliary drainage using endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). Biliary stones are the primary cause of cholangitis and can be removed by endoscopic sphincterotomy during ERCP.
  • ➤ Cholangitis is an infection of the common bile duct caused by obstruction and increased pressure due to CBD stones.
  • ➤ The classical triad of cholangitis (Charcot) is fever, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice.
  • ➤ If left untreated, cholangitis can progress to Reynold's pentad with hypotension and altered mental status due to sepsis.
  • ➤ Abdominal ultrasound is used to diagnose biliary stones and bile duct dilatations in cholangitis.
  • ➤ Treatment for cholangitis includes broad-spectrum antibiotics, rehydration, and biliary drainage using endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).
  • ➤ Biliary stones are the primary cause of cholangitis and can be removed by endoscopic sphincterotomy during ERCP.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient is brought to the ER following a suspected stroke. The patient is unable to speak fluently, though he understands the given instructions. Which category of aphasia is most likely present in the patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Broca's aphasia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient in the question exhibits symptoms consistent with Broca's aphasia, also known as motor aphasia. In Broca's aphasia, the patient has difficulty with speech production and articulation but maintains relatively intact language comprehension. This is evident from the fact that the patient understands the given instructions but is unable to speak fluently.
  • • Broca's area, located in the frontal lobe (Brodmann areas 44 and 45), is responsible for speech production and articulation. Damage to this area, often caused by a stroke, results in Broca's aphasia. Patients with Broca's aphasia struggle with fluent speech but can typically understand language, as the Wernicke's area remains unaffected.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Wernicke's aphasia : This is a form of sensory aphasia where patients have difficulty understanding language but can produce fluent, albeit meaningless, speech. Wernicke’s area is located at the Posterior part of area no 22. This is associated with hearing loss.
  • • Option B. Wernicke's aphasia
  • • Option C. Conduction aphasia : In this type of aphasia, the patient can understand and produce language, but there is a disconnect between the Wernicke's area and the Broca's area (Brodmann areas 39 and 40). This results in difficulty repeating words or phrases, which is not mentioned in the patient's case.
  • • Option C. Conduction aphasia
  • • Option D. Global aphasia : This is a severe form of aphasia involving both Broca's and Wernicke's areas, leading to impairments in both language production and comprehension. The patient in the question does not exhibit signs of impaired comprehension, making this option incorrect.
  • • Option D. Global aphasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Broca's aphasia, or motor aphasia, is characterized by difficulty in speech production and articulation while language comprehension remains relatively intact. It is caused by damage to Broca's area (Brodmann areas 44 and 45) in the frontal lobe, often due to a stroke.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presented with chest pain. In an angiogram, her left circumflex artery was found to be stenosed, and a stent was inserted. Her current medications include ASA 75mg OD, atenolol 50mg BID, lovastatin, and lisinopril. What should be done in this scenario? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Add P2Y12 receptor inhibitor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ After stent placement, dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor) is essential to prevent stent thrombosis and ensure optimal patient outcomes.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with symptoms of inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits. He was also not able to hold a piece of paper between his fingers. What is the likely site of injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. C

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • An ulnar nerve damage is suggested by the clinical scenario, which includes a positive card test and the inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits.
  • • The most likely site of injury would thus be medial epicondyle: site C
  • • Damage to the ulnar nerve at the medial epicondyle causes paralysis of the flexor carpi ulnaris (lack of ulnar deviation) and the medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus (loss of distal interphalangeal joint flexion). Hypothenar paralysis (which causes atrophy) and sensory loss are the results. Moreover, the extensor digitorum and flexor digitorum superficialis (provided by the radial nerve and median nerve, respectively) continue to function. The third and fourth digits are therefore not completely paralysed. The palmar interossei's fragility, which causes a loss of adduction, is what causes the positive card test.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Head of the Humerus: Articulates with the shoulder joint. Injury here typically affects shoulder movement, not the distal functions like finger flexion or sensory issues associated with the ulnar nerve.
  • • Option A. Head of the Humerus:
  • • Option B. Intertubercular Groove: Houses the tendon of the biceps brachii. Mainly affects movements related to the biceps muscle, not ulnar nerve functions.
  • • Option B. Intertubercular Groove:
  • • Option D. Lateral Epicondyle: Attachment site for forearm extensor muscles. Primarily involved in conditions like lateral epicondylitis, which causes localized pain rather than the broader sensory and motor deficits seen in ulnar nerve damage.
  • • Option D. Lateral Epicondyle:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ulnar nerve branches and supply:
  • ➤ Ulnar nerve branches and supply:
  • ➤ Superficial branch supplies palmaris brevis, skin on the palmar surface of medial 1½ fingers. The deep branch runs within the concavity of deep palmar arch and supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand (except first 2 lumbricals and thenar muscles).

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered as a factor for a high-risk pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.correct_answer: D. Previous manual removal of placenta
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Previous manual removal of placenta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Previous manual removal of the placenta does not automatically categorize a subsequent pregnancy as high-risk. High-risk pregnancies are characterized by various factors that may complicate the pregnancy or pose risks to the mother and fetus. These factors include existing health conditions, certain lifestyle factors, age-related risks, and specific pregnancy conditions.
  • • High-risk pregnancy factors according to the NIH include:
  • • High-risk pregnancy factors according to the NIH include:
  • • Existing health conditions: Hypertension Diabetes Autoimmune diseases PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome) Thyroid disorders Obesity HIV Anemia Uterine fibroids Age: Adolescence First-time pregnancy at age >35 years Lifestyle factors: Alcohol consumption Smoking Drug use Pregnancy conditions: Multiple pregnancy Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) Pre-eclampsia Previous preterm birth Congenital or chromosomal anomalies Polyhydramnios or oligohydramnios Rh iso-immunization Antepartum hemorrhage Fetal growth restriction
  • • Existing health conditions: Hypertension Diabetes Autoimmune diseases PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome) Thyroid disorders Obesity HIV Anemia Uterine fibroids
  • • Existing health conditions:
  • • Hypertension Diabetes Autoimmune diseases PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome) Thyroid disorders Obesity HIV Anemia Uterine fibroids
  • • Hypertension
  • • Diabetes
  • • Autoimmune diseases
  • • PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome)
  • • Thyroid disorders
  • • Obesity
  • • HIV
  • • Anemia
  • • Uterine fibroids
  • • Age: Adolescence First-time pregnancy at age >35 years
  • • Age:
  • • Adolescence First-time pregnancy at age >35 years
  • • Adolescence
  • • First-time pregnancy at age >35 years
  • • Lifestyle factors: Alcohol consumption Smoking Drug use
  • • Lifestyle factors:
  • • Alcohol consumption Smoking Drug use
  • • Alcohol consumption
  • • Smoking
  • • Drug use
  • • Pregnancy conditions: Multiple pregnancy Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) Pre-eclampsia Previous preterm birth Congenital or chromosomal anomalies Polyhydramnios or oligohydramnios Rh iso-immunization Antepartum hemorrhage Fetal growth restriction
  • • Pregnancy conditions:
  • • Multiple pregnancy Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) Pre-eclampsia Previous preterm birth Congenital or chromosomal anomalies Polyhydramnios or oligohydramnios Rh iso-immunization Antepartum hemorrhage Fetal growth restriction
  • • Multiple pregnancy
  • • Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)
  • • Pre-eclampsia
  • • Previous preterm birth
  • • Congenital or chromosomal anomalies
  • • Polyhydramnios or oligohydramnios
  • • Rh iso-immunization
  • • Antepartum hemorrhage
  • • Fetal growth restriction
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Obesity : Obesity is a significant factor for a high-risk pregnancy as it is associated with various complications such as gestational diabetes, pre-eclampsia, and increased risk of cesarean delivery.
  • • Option A. Obesity
  • • Option B. Polyhydramnios : Polyhydramnios, which is an excessive amount of amniotic fluid, can lead to complications such as preterm labor and fetal malformations, making it a high-risk condition.
  • • Option B. Polyhydramnios
  • • Option C. Anemia : Anemia during pregnancy can affect the health of both the mother and the fetus, leading to conditions such as preterm birth and low birth weight, thus categorizing it as high-risk.
  • • Option C. Anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Previous manual removal of the placenta is not considered a factor for categorizing a subsequent pregnancy as high-risk.
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/high-risk
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/high-risk

questions.text: A physician is preparing to administer post-exposure prophylaxis for a patient who has been bitten by a potentially rabid animal. Which of the following statements about the administration of rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is INCORRECT? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: It is exclusively given in the deltoid

options.label: C
options.text: Not given after 7 days of the 1st dose of the vaccine

options.label: D
options.text: If human RIG is unavailable, equine is preferred

questions.correct_answer: A. It is exclusively given in the deltoid
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) It is exclusively given in the deltoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) should be infiltrated around the wound site and any remaining dose given intramuscularly, preferably in the deltoid, but it is not exclusively given in the deltoid.
  • ➤ Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) should be infiltrated around the wound site and any remaining dose given intramuscularly, preferably in the deltoid, but it is not exclusively given in the deltoid.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with hearing loss and tinnitus. A histology image is shown below. What can be the diagnosis for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Schwannoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Schwannoma is a benign tumor often associated with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, diagnosed via characteristic histological patterns and confirmed with MRI. It requires careful management, sometimes involving advanced surgical techniques such as Gamma Knife surgery.

questions.text: Following delivery of a preterm baby, the baby died in the NICU despite all efforts. What medication would be given to the mother for reducing breast tenderness? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cabergoline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cabergoline is the preferred medication for suppressing lactation and reducing breast tenderness in cases where breastfeeding is not desired or possible, such as after neonatal death

questions.text: A child presents with cold feet and a history of wearing socks even in the summers. On examination, lower limb pulses are diminished as compared to the radial pulse. Prominent radio femoral delay is present. What is the underlying condition? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: There is hypertrophy of ductus arteriosus.

options.label: B
options.text: Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery

options.label: C
options.text: Supply is from posterior to anterior thoracic artery.

options.label: D
options.text: Collaterals develop to supply upper limb.

questions.correct_answer: B. Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coarctation of the aorta typically presents with cold feet, diminished lower limb pulses, and radiofemoral delay due to a narrowing of the aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with substernal chest discomfort. On examination, he was hypotensive, drowsy, and had unequal pulses. Which of the following investigations would be the best in this situation to ascertain the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Trans-esophageal echocardiography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the setting of suspected aortic dissection, especially in an unstable patient, trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the best diagnostic tool due to its high sensitivity and ability to be performed at the bedside, providing rapid and accurate confirmation of the diagnosis.

questions.text: Case fatality rate of the disease rabies is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Case fatality rate (CFR) is used to measure the virulence of organism or killing power of a disease. CFR for COVID-19 and Chickenpox is about 1%. Measles has a CFR of 3%. Rabies has the highest CFR at nearly 100%, with no cure available once symptoms appear.
  • ➤ Case fatality rate (CFR) is used to measure the virulence of organism or killing power of a disease.
  • ➤ CFR for COVID-19 and Chickenpox is about 1%.
  • ➤ Measles has a CFR of 3%.
  • ➤ Rabies has the highest CFR at nearly 100%, with no cure available once symptoms appear.

questions.text: A person who at the time of commission of the offense was of unsound mind, is exempt if he didn't know the nature of the act or its consequences. This rule is known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) McNaughton rule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In India, the McNaughton rule is used to determine criminal responsibility for individuals with mental illness. According to this rule, a person is exempt from criminal responsibility if they were unable to understand the nature of their act or know that it was wrong due to their mental condition.

questions.text: Which of the following supplement is required more for a lactating woman than the pregnant female? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin A is required more for a lactating woman than a pregnant female. This increased need ensures that there is enough vitamin A in breast milk to support the baby's growth and development, particularly for their immune system and vision.
  • ➤ Vitamins and mineral requirement for pregnant and lactating women
  • ➤ Vitamins and mineral requirement for pregnant and lactating women
  • ➤ The above table shows the Vitamins A and C are required in significantly higher quantity during the lactation while Folate and iron are required in higher quantity during pregnancy. All other minerals and vitamin (Not shown in table) have similar requirements under both conditions.

questions.text: An infertile patient came with a history of sinus inversus, sinusitis, and pulmonary infection. Which syndrome is likely to occur? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis is characteristic of Kartagener syndrome, which is a subtype of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) resulting from dysfunctional cilia.
